Award.AwardTitle: Biogenesis and evolution of fungal telomerase RNA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The telomerase enzyme is crucial for maintaining genome stability and cellular immortality. Elucidating novel telomerase biogenesis pathways and protein-RNA co-evolution in unexplored fungal groups will reveal fundamental principles of enzyme evolution in biology. Notably, the fungi included in this study are known pathogens of amphibians and food crops. This project will involve training of high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented minority groups. These students will have hands-on laboratory experiences that will motivate and encourage them to pursue careers in STEM disciplines. Moreover, the research experience will improve their applications and competitiveness for college and graduate school. Students will also participate in updating and improving our publicly accessible Telomerase Database, which serves as an effective means of disseminating hypothesis- and curiosity-driven research to the general public.

Telomerase ribonucleoprotein (RNP) composition and biogenesis pathways are extremely divergent among distinct groups of eukaryotes. The origins and evolutionary connections among telomerase RNAs (TR) from different groups of species remain unresolved. To understand the mechanism driving telomerase RNP diversity, telomerases from distinct representative taxa within eukaryotes need to be studied. This project will employ molecular biology and biochemical approaches for identifying TRs from key fungal species outside of the previously explored Ascomycota phylum. The newly identified TRs will offer novel, exciting models for telomerase RNP structure-function and biogenesis. Collectively, this project will provide crucial insights into the molecular evolution of fungal telomerase RNP structure-function and expand our knowledge of lncRNA (long noncoding RNA) biogenesis pathways.

The project is funded jointly by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Division of Biological Infrastructure in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) enzyme that contains both protein and RNA components. Uniquely, the composition and biogenesis of the telomerase RNP complex are extremely divergent among distinct groups of eukaryotes. Elucidating novel telomerase biogenesis pathways and protein-RNA co-evolution in previously unexplored groups from diverse eukaryotic kingdoms will reveal fundamental principles of enzyme evolution in biology. In this research program, we initially aimed to explore the diversity of fungal telomerase biogenesis pathways in the previously unexplored basidiomycota phylum, the sister phylum of Ascomycota. We have successfully identified telomerase RNA component from a basidiomycota fungus Ustilgo maydis and its related species using a unique approach combining biochemical purification of telomerase holoenzyme and phylogeny-assisted bioinformatics analysis. By detailed structural and functional studies of the identified U. maydis telomerase RNA, we discovered a novel biogenesis pathway of fungal telomerase RNA with which the telomerase RNA is derived from a protein-coding message RNA molecule. This work expands our understanding of the telomerase RNP enzyme processing and evolution. Moreover, leveraging our productive approach which was invented explicitly for searching divergent telomerase RNA sequences, we identified more than 80 telomerase RNA genes from previously unexplored invertebrate phyla across the entire animal kingdom. We then functionally validated the identified animal telomerase RNAs from select species by in vitrotelomerase activity reconstitution. Despite the extreme divergence in primary sequence, our results indicated a monophyletic origin of animal telomerase RNA. They all share a common biogenesis pathway and revealed attractive diversification of crucial structural elements along specific animal lineages. This finding demonstrates how our effective phylogeny-guided computational strategy overcomes significant roadblocks in the study of telomerase evolution. In addition to animal telomerase, we collaborated with the Shippen lab from the Texas A&M University to study the plant telomerase by developing an in vitro reconstitution system and establishing a reliable secondary structure model for plant telomerase RNA. Lastly, this research program also involved the training of two postdoctoral fellows, three PhD students, four undergraduates, and three high school students. These students had hands-on laboratory experiences that motivate and encourage them to pursue careers in STEM disciplines. Students also participated in updating and improving our publicly accessible Telomerase Database, which serves as an effective means of disseminating hypothesis- and curiosity-driven research to the general public.
